content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would opt for strategy R{R}. The reason behind this choice is that if both players consistently choose the same strategy, they will earn the highest possible payoff at the end of the game. In this case, choosing R means earning 45$ when my partner chooses R and 35$ when they choose B.

However, since I have no way of knowing my partner's strategy, I would assume that they are rational players who want to maximize their earnings as well. This makes it likely that they will choose the same strategy consistently as well.

In a best-case scenario for me (and for them), we both pick R in every round, earning 45$ each time. In a worst-case scenario, I still come out ahead by picking R because if my partner picks B in any round, they will only earn 0$, while I will get 35$.

Given that the game has 75 rounds and there's no way to know how my partner will play, consistently choosing R seems like the best strategy overall.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I would choose R again for the next round. The reason behind this choice is that even though my opponent chose B in the previous round and earned 35$, they still have an incentive to switch their strategy to R in future rounds since it will earn them more money if both of us choose R.

In other words, I believe that by consistently choosing R, I may encourage my opponent to change their strategy and eventually end up with the highest possible payoff for myself (45$ per round) or a higher payoff compared to sticking with B every time.

By playing R again, I keep open the possibility of earning 45$ in future rounds if my opponent switches to R. If they do not switch their strategy, I will still earn 35$ per round instead of 0$. In this game, since there are no penalties for changing strategies and the payoffs are relatively high compared to the potential losses when both players choose different strategies, it makes sense to continue playing R in the hope of encouraging my opponent to switch.
